narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: There was a lot of interesting material covered in the class but I didn't feel like the material was very tightly organized.

The course felt generally unorganized. Having two professors seems like a good idea, and could certainly work if there was more organization. Bradford was considerably better than Raymond.The readings were nonexistent for the first part of the semester.

I was an auditor and so don't have responses for many of the questions. I very much appreciated the chance to audit and felt that the course tied together many areas of knowledge that before were quite disconnected in my mind.
This class was not as valuable for me because the content overlapped with some other classes.
It was actually well structured in terms of the themes approached and the order. Quite bold.
Paper discussion and group presentation
I liked the discussion sessions of the class, I think they should have been spaced out along the length of semester instead of clustered right at the end of the class.
Freedom to choose our presentation topicDiscussion of very new, frontier topics in sci
The professors worked fairly well together and provided different perspectives and areas of knowledge.Assignments were useful and not too time consuming (i.e. not busy work).
Mark Bradford's lectures&the discussions
The paper discussions during the last portion of the semester were good. Wouldn't want to expand to the whole course.
The paper discussions were interesting.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I felt like the exams were only vaguely related to the lectures and the homework assignments didn't help in preparation for the exams. The instructors also assumed that most people in the class had prior science backgrounds, which made it difficult. Lectures were fairly dull and seemed to be read straight off the powerpoint.
More effort needs to go into actually preparing the course. Reading materials felt somewhat random and assignments superficial. The grading of the exams felt also opaque with little feedback.

As just mentioned, the discussions need to be spaced throughout the semester; having them all in a row was difficult and I felt like they started to lag towards the end--it was hard to keep motivated over five classes of discussions in a row. Also, grouping the discussions with the presentation so closely together made for a lot of work grouped in a pretty intensive time period; again, I think it would be better to space these assignments out.

During the week of discussions, as there are 2 proffs and one TA, consider breaking the class up into smaller discussion groupsClearer guidelines and higher expectations for student presentations to facilitate more discussionSeveral lectures towards the end of the semester, circa the Stoichiometry lecture, created quite a bit of confusion for several students -- having more introductory readings might help
Maybe provide readings as assignments earlier in the class, especially if the papers will be discussed in lecture.

The discussions may have been better if the class size was better. The ecological stoichiometry discussion in particular was not very helpful. Fewer readings and/or closer readings may have been helpful to narrow down students prep time so that they would be more engaged.
The slides were sometimes difficult to follow and had some extraneous information, figures etc. Streamlining would be really great.
This was a solid introduction to Ecosystem Science, but at times it seemed a little bit basic, and I think that the expectations could have been set higher.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Ok
Always available when contacted, but only contacted once (both the TA and professor)
The instructors and TA were very helpful when I came to them for help or advice.
we got a lot of help from the instructor during our preparation for the group presentation.

Mark Bradford availed himself to help out during the presentation period of the course--he provided useful feedback and suggestions. Ashley held one TA session. I didn't find too much need for extra help throughout the course of the semester, so didn't take advantage of what was necessarily available.
All were very responsive, kind, patient, and helpful
All three were very helpful and available.
Good

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course was important for my education because I am wanting to learn more about ecology and ecosystem functioning.
It complement the biological and ecological knowledge to my background.

I wanted to gain a basic understanding of ecosystem science. Having never taken an ecosystem class before, this class did provide just that. It was pretty basic. A lot of generalized overviews--I found the discussions worthwhile as it allowed us to dig in to the material more, but it's hardto have a discussion when the class is so big.

This course fit well with Landscape ecology and Biodiversity Conservation. There was very little overlap. This course provided a good overview of ecological concepts at a different scale than the other classes (i.e. nutrient cycling, etc.)
general biological science req for MF
As I mentioned previously, it turned out to be somewhat helpful but not very helpful for my overall program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Bin requirement. It was actually a lot more interesting than I thought.
To fulfill a bin requirement.
I took this course because I thought it would be interesting and it would be helpful to my education.
It is useful for my future work.
To get a basic ecosystem science background.
MEM Bin Requirement and general interest
To gain a better understanding of ecosystem functions.
General ecology background missing in undergrad

I was looking for an introductory Ecology course because I am unfamiliar with the topic in general. I believe the title, and to some degree the description, implied that there would be more theoretical "pattern& process" content instead of the very descriptive, system specific information that was given.
Partially in order to fulfill a graduation requirement, and partially because I was interested to learn about the conceptual framework of ecosystem ecology.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: The subject was better than I though but the preparation for the course was quite lacking.
Yea, I think so.
Not really. The class was basic--and I think it should be offered as solely undergrad course next year. A more worthwhile grad class could be a smaller seminar with more discussions.
Yes
Yes, it was exactly what I was looking for.
yes
No, not really.
No, not really.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes
Yes
yes
It was good to be introduced to ecological systems.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: What do you mean advantages and disadvantages of group work? This is unclear.
We were doing work in a group. It help a lot our teamwork capability. And we can work on the thesis very thoroughly.

I had a great group--everyone worked hard and followed through with their share of their obligations. This was actually one of the better group assignment experiences I've had since at FES, but I think that had to do with being able to chose our group rather than being arbitrarily assigned. Advantages included being able to tackle a broad range of the material individually and synthesizing it together.
Decreases workload and is good practice at delegating and organizing.
covered a lot of ground - group work always an important work skill learning point.
It made the project quite manageable, particularly because of the literature review.
My group mates were extremely busy with other schoolwork, so it was difficult to galvanize the group.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The subject and the professors' courage in approaching major and interesting themes made up for their lack of preparation and superficiality in coming up with a reading list and assignments. Take the course.
If you want a really basic ecosystem class that has minimal reading, take it. It's not too hard and not too much work.
Get to know your professors. They are entertaining.
do some of the outside readings to get more out of the lectures.
Eh.
You might want to carefully consider whether or not there will be much overlap with other classes that you have taken or will take.
